bibl.note: This document is a letter from Cherokee agent Return J. Meigs to General Andrew Jackson written on July 6, 1816. Meigs is telling Jackson about a convention he attended with the Cherokees in order to establish the boundary line of their land. He says that the lands given up by the Cherokee will benefit both the Cherokee and the United States because of land-holding and monetary issues.

div1.p:
I was at the City when the Convention with the Cherokees was made settling their boundary line: The Secretary of War at that time made a proposition to the Cherokees then there as a deputation, to
unk cede to the
U Statesall their claims to lands lying west of a line to be run due South from that point on the
Tennessee river
which intersected by the Eastern boundary of Madison County to the line agreed upon by the said convention. The Cherokee Deputation did not Consider themselves authorised to cede land. Before I came away the secretary told me that a treaty would be ordered to be held in order to obtain some cessions of land from the Cherokees that I must make my best exertions to effect the Objects. I am now instructed
to open negotiations with the Cherokees for the purpose afordd. and shall omit nothing in my power to obtain the Cession of the lands mentioned also the the cherokee lands lying on the North side of the Tennessee river . nothing but a cession of the lands first mentioned will put an end to the
Chickesaw claim to the same lands, or most of them; that is one reason why they aught to sue. Another reason is they hold too much land, this only retards their improvement in civilization onother reason is they are in Debt they want money to pay their debts to make provisions forselcoots? other improvements The Cherokee chiefs particularly those who were in the Army all know and respect you; your opinion advise would have more effect on them than that of any other man on the face of the earth and should it be in your
way to express your sentiments to
colo Richard Brown
Colo I Lowry on the subject of one or of both these cessions you would lay me under vary great obligations whch if in my power I would make proper return in any way you should command me.

closer.salute:
I have the honor to be
with greatest respect
Yr Obt Servant
